ratings.question_text: Overall, how would you rate the workload of this course in comparison to other Yale courses you have taken?
What is your overall assessment of this course?
Do you expect to use this class for credit toward your major, or toward a pre-professional program?

narratives.question_text: How would you summarize ECON 110 05 for a fellow student? Would you recommend ECON 110 05 to another student? Why or why not?
comments: A class on lobsters, fish, and why the government will always fail to effectively protect the environment. If you do none of the reading for the rest of the class, be sure to read all of Ostrom's stuff. You'll need it for the term paper.

much more environmental studies than epe/poli sci focused. great class if you're interested in common pool resources especially in regards to the New England fishing industry. a little confusing at times in regards to where it's headed, but makes you think for sure.

I recommend this course for students interested in governance and complex issues of policy in terms of collective action problems. It's important to note that this course is about governing institutions and not policy...I'd say that if you're interested in this topic, this course would be highly productive.
I would recommend it if you're interested in fisheries management.

If youâre interested in the governance of natural resources or the intersection of science and politics, Iâd strongly recommend Democracy and Sustainability to you. The first third of this seminar reviews the political theory underlying common-pool resource management, especially Elinor Ostromâs IAD framework. The rest of the course uses this theoretical foundation to examine several case studies, with a special focus on New England fisheries.Prof. Fotos is an outstanding professor who facilitates interestingâand sometimes heatedâ discussions about each weekâs readings. Although the reading load may seem intimidating, Prof. Fotosâs weekly memos will help you direct your attention to the most important parts. He gives you a lot of freedom to choose your own paper topic and is eager to work with you to develop and refine your ideas. Furthermore, this seminar is accessible to students who donât plan to major in political science, particularly those who have a strong background in the physical, environmental, and life sciences. Overall, if you can get excited about the material and find a paper topic that interests you, I think youâll enjoy this class and will gain a new perspective on the environmental problems contemporary society must confront.

Professor Fotos asks the most challenging and pressing questions for environmental politics, and policy making in general. I recommend this class for environmental studies majors, and political science majors with any interest in tackling issues related to governing the commons. You will find your place in the great mix of students that take and contribute to this class! Fotos creates an open and good-humored forum for discussion. The readings are highly diverse in structure, content, and length. Most of them aren't too dense; just some of the social theory and political philosophy themed readings at the beginning of the course. Most of material is manageable for any EVST or PLSC major, no matter the background.
